title: DNS: The Internet's Phone Book
description: A quick, practical guide to DNS: The Internet's Phone Book.

hook.text: You type 'google.com' but your computer needs a number. Something translates that name â€” and it can be hijacked.

buildup.text: DNS translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses. Without it, you'd need to memorize numbers for.

discovery.text: DNS queries are usually unencrypted. Anyone monitoring your network can see every website you're trying to visit.

twist.text: DNS hijacking redirects your queries to fake servers. You type your bank's URL and arrive at an attacker's replica.

climax.text: DNS is critical infrastructure that most users never think about â€” which makes it a prime target for attacks.

punchline.text: You typed the right address. DNS sent you to the wrong place.

quiz.question: Why is DNS a security concern?
options: DNS queries are often unencrypted and can be hijacked to redirect users
